data.title: The Legend of Stan Bowman
data.meta_description: This story describes United States Auto Club (USAC) sprint car racing in the early 1960s.
data.text:
♪ >> HE WAS THE GREATEST RACE CAR DRIVER I'VE EVER SEEN IN MY LIFE.

>> HE COULD TAKE A WHEEL BAR AND PUT IT OUT FRONT.

>> HE WAS ONE OF THE TOP GUYS IN SPRINT CARS, ABSOLUTELY.

I THINK HE WAS DEFINITELY READY TO PROGRESS TO GET TO THE TOP LEVEL, NO QUESTION ABOUT THAT.

>> I KIND OF THOUGHT, BOY, I LEFT SOMETHING LAYING ON THE TABLE.

WISH HE HAD BEEN DRIVING FOR US.

>> HE WAS THE NEW KID ON THE BLOCK, BUT HE CAME ON LEADING THE PARADE, AND THAT WAS REALLY SOMETHING.

>> WITH HIS ABILITY, AND HIS ATTITUDE TO GO FAST, FAST WASN'T FAST ENOUGH FOR HIM.

>> AS A YOUNG MAN, STAN BOWMAN LEARNED TO DRIVE ON THE CURVEY ROADS AND ROLLING HILLS OF SOUTHERN INDIANA.

HIS PASSION FOR SPEED LED HIM TO LOCAL RACETRACKS IN LOUISVILLE, KENTUCKY, WHERE HE BEGAN HIS RACING CAREER.

IN 1955, STAN, HIS WIFE MARJORIE AND SON RANDY, MOVED TO COVINGTON, KENTUCKY, TO BE CLOSER TO HIS DAY JOB AS A HEAVY EQUIPMENT OPERATOR BUILDING INTERSTATE 75.

>> UNTIL WE MOVED UP HERE, YOU KNOW, GREATER CINCINNATI TO NORTHERN KENTUCKY, THAT'S WHERE I CAN, BASICALLY REMEMBER LIKE GOING TO HILLTOP AND LAWRENCEBURG AND GLEN ESTE AND ALL THE LOCAL TRACKS.

LIKE WHEN I WAS 8, 9, 10 YEARS OLD.

BECAUSE THAT'S WHERE WE WERE EVERY WEEKEND.

>> PRETTY GOOD ALL-AROUND GUY.

I GOT TO KNOW HIM PRETTY WELL PROBABLY ABOUT 1957.

WE WERE RUNNING AT THE CINCINNATI RACE BOWL.

HE CAME AROUND.

HE WAS FROM OVER IN INDIANA SOMEWHERE.

HE WASN'T A BIG STAR IN THE BEGINNING, BUT HE SEEMED TO ACQUIRE THE ABILITY TO ADAPT TO ANY RACE CAR HE GOT IN AND GO FAST.

>> HE WORKED, YOU KNOW, CONSTRUCTION WORK THROUGH THE WEEK, BUT EVERY SATURDAY WE WAS RACING SOMEWHERE, AND I WAS ALWAYS THERE, TOO.

JUST LIKE DADDY'S LITTLE BOY.

>> STAN BEGAN MAKING A NAME FOR HIMSELF AT HILLTOP SPEEDWAY IN INDEPENDENCE, KENTUCKY.

>> IT WAS KIND OF A ROUGH, DUSTY RACETRACK, YOU KNOW.

HE COULD TAKE A ROUGH TRACK AND MAKE IT LOOK SMOOTH.

>> HE ALSO DID SOME THRILL SHOW STUFF.

I REMEMBER SEEING THAT ONE TIME, WHERE THEY WOULD HAVE THESE THRILL SHOWS THAT WOULD COME AROUND.

JOEY CHITWOOD IS THE MOST FAMOUS ONE, BUT THERE WERE OTHERS.

AND STAN WOULD GET IN AN OLD CAR AND TURN IT OVER, RUN IT ON A RAMP AND TURN IT OVER THREE OR FOUR FOUR TIMES WALK AWAY OR GO THROUGH A WALL O SO, YOU COULDN'T DENY A FELLA LI THAT NOT GETTING YOUR ATTENTION A LITTLE BIT.

THAT'S HOW IT STARTED.

>> FIRST TIME I EVER DROVE A RACE CAR WAS HILLTOP SPEEDWAY TH NORTHERN KENTUCKY.

STAN WAS UP THERE WITH MY DAD HAVING FRIED CHICKEN AFTER THE RACE WAS OVER.

AND I TOOK IT OUT AND GAVE IT A PRETTY GOOD RIDE.

AND STAN TOLD MY DAD, SAYS CHARLIE, THAT'S YOUR CAR OUT THERE ON THE TRACK.

DAD SAYS, NO, IT CAN'T BE.

IT'S MAKING TOO MUCH NOISE.

MY CAR IS NOT THAT LOUD.

AND STAN SAID, "IT SURE IS."

AND AFTER I GOT OUT OF THE CAR AND WENT RUNNING BACK UP TO WHERE THEY WERE, THEY WERE STILL EATING FRIED CHICKEN.

STAN WAS RAZZING ME ABOUT IT AND SAID I THOUGHT YOU WERE GOING TO BLOW THAT THING UP.

YOU KNOW, JUST AGGRAVATING MY DAD, I GUESS, MORE THAN ANYTHING.

THEY ALWAYS LIKED TO KID MY DAD.

>> HE WAS A GOOD GUY AND ONE HELL OF A RACE CAR DRIVER.

I MEAN HE TAUGHT ME MORE-- TALKED TO ME, HE COME OVER TO MY HOUSE AND DRINK COFFEE, AND WE WOULD SIT THERE AND RACE AT THE KITCHEN TABLE, YOU KNOW.

AND HE TAUGHT ME MORE ABOUT RACING AND I STILL REMEMBER IT.

>> BUZZ ON STAN BOWMAN STARTED IN ABOUT 1959.

STAN STARTED DRIVING A MODIFIED CAR FOR A FELLA NAMED GEORGE CONNER WHO HAD A RACING-- HAD A GARAGE, AND HE KEPT A CAR THERE IN COVINGTON, KENTUCKY.

AND HE WAS SUCCESSFUL FROM THE BEGINNING.

AND NO MATTER WHERE STAN STARTED, YOU KNEW AT THE END OF THE RACE, HE WAS EITHER GOING TO BE FIRST, SECOND OR THIRD SEEMED EVERY WEEK, WHAT YOU COUNTED ON.

AND I'LL SAY THIS.

GEORGE CONNERS, I THINK, WAS A GREAT MENTOR FOR STAN BOWMAN.

>> MY DAD WON A LOT.

SO I'M SURE THAT MADE IT EASIER.

AND HE WAS, YOU KNOW, HE WAS LIKED.

HE HAD A FOLLOWING.

>> IN THE SPRING OF 1962, STAN BOWMAN MOVED UP TO THE SECOND HIGHEST LEVEL OF RACING IN THE UNITED STATES AUTO CLUB.

>> (LAUGHS) MY FAVORITE DEFINITI SPRINT CAR IS LIKE SLAPPING A MOUNTAIN LION IN THE BEHIND WITH A HAND FULL OF COCKLEBURS.

YOU JUST BETTER BE READY.

(LAUG >> WELL, IT'S SPRINT CAR BECAUSE WE DON'T RUN LONG RACES.

OUR RACES ARE 30, SOMETIMES 50 LAPS.

TYPICALLY WE NEVER RUN LONG RACES AND THAT'S WHERE THE WORD SPRINT COMES FROM.

BUT YOU HAVE A SERIES OF EVENTS THAT LEAD TO THE FEATURE EVENT.

AND PARTICULARLY THEY RUN ON BOTH PAVEMENT AND DIRT, BUT DIRT IS THE MOST POPULAR.

>> EXCITING OBVIOUSLY.

I THINK THE SPRINT CARS OBVIOUSLY, PROBABLY THE MOST, LET'S JUST SAY THE MOST BEASTLY RACE CAR YOU COULD EVER DRIVE BECAUSE THE POWER TO RATIO, AND THE HORSEPOWER YOU HAVE BECAUSE OF THE LOW GEARS.

>> EVERY NOW AND THEN HAVE YOU TO GO TO THE EDGE AND LOOK OVER.

IF YOU DON'T, IT GETS A LITTLE BORING AROUND HERE.

AND SO THAT'S WHAT SPRINT CAR RACING WAS.

IT TOOK THE BORING PART OF IT OUT AND IT WAS EXCITING, VERY EXCITING.

>> THAT WAS PROBABLY THE BEST LAUNCHING PAD FOR ME BECAUSE WHY?

BECAUSE YOU WERE RACING AGAINST ALL THE TOP GUYS, YOU KNOW, McCLUSKEY, FOYT, BRANSON AND THE UNCERS AND SO ON AMD SO FORT YOU WERE MEASURING UP AGAINST THE GUY YOU WERE GOING TO BE MEASURING UP WHEN YOU ADVANCED TO THE NEXT LEVEL.

SO IT WAS THAT IMPORTANT.

>> THERE ARE GOOD DRIVERS AND THERE ARE MEDIOCRE DRIVERS AND THERE ARE INCREDIBLE DRIVERS.

AND I ASKED DAN GURNEY THAT SAME QUESTION.

AND HE SAID, HE'S KIND OF LIKE THIS.

HE SAYS, YOU KNOW, IMAGINE SOMEB WALKING ALONG THE GRAND CANYON, ON A BIG CLIFF, AND HE'S WALKING ALONG THERE AND ONE FOOT IN FRONT OF THE OTHER.

THAT'S PRETTY RISKY.

AND BUT HE CAN DO IT.

AND HE SAYS NOW, THINK OF ONE GU THAT'S WALKING ALONG THAT EDGE W ONE FOOT, HOPPING ALONG.

THAT GUY IS REALLY INCREDIBLE.

HE SAID THAT'S KIND OF LIKE THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN AN INCREDIBLE DRIVER AND A GOOD DRIVER.

>> IT WAS FUN RACING.

OF ALL THE RACING THAT I'VE DONE, I THINK I ENJOYED SPRINT CARS JUST ABOUT AS MUCH AS I DID THE INDY CARS BECAUSE IT WAS REAL RACING.

>> WHERE, BACK THEN, I DON'T KNOW IF THEY RAN WIDE OPEN OR NOT.

I DOUBT IT.

I HOPE THEY WEREN'T.

BUT ON THAT SKINNY AND THAT HARD OF A TIRE, AND THE SUSPENSIONS WEREN'T FANCY WITH FANCY SHOCKS WITH WHAT WE HAVE NOWADAYS, I CAN PROMISE YOU IT WAS A LOT MORE OF A HANDFUL TO FIGURE OUT HOW TO GET THE CAR STUCK GOING THROUGH THE CORNERS.

>> SO, THOSE DRIVERS WERE REALLY WORKING IT.

>> UN HM, ABSOLUTELY.

I CAN PROMISE YOU THEY WERE WORKING MUCH HARDER THAN WHAT WE ARE RIGHT NOW.

>> NOW THAT THE CARS HAVE GOT ALL OF THE SUPPORTIVE WINGS ON TOP AND 800 OR 900 HORSEPOWER ENGINES AND TIRES THAT ARE 16 INCHES WIDE AND, YOU KNOW, GIVE ME A BREAK.

THAT'S NOT-- WELL, THAT'S RACING TODAY.

>> I'M JUST SO HAPPY AND FORTUNATE THAT I WAS ABLE TO HAVE MY LICKS IN SPRINT CARS BECAUSE I THINK WHEN I LOOK AT SOME OF THE YOUNGER DRIVERS, AND OBVIOUSLY NEVER HAD THE OPPORTUNITY, GOSH, WHAT THEY MISSED.

I MEAN AS A DRIVER, YOU KNOW WHAT, IF YOU HAD THAT EXPERIENCE, YOU WOULDN'T TRADE IT FOR ANYTHING.

>> I WOULD GIVE UP MY THREE-CUP CHAMPIONSHIPS, MY KNEE CAR CHAMPIONSHIP, MY USAC CHAMPIONSHIPS, I WOULD GIVE IT ALL UP TO HAVE THAT OPPORTUNITY TO RACE WITH THOSE GUYS IN THAT ERA.

THAT, TO ME, WAS SOME OF THE BEST TIMES IN AUTO RACING.

>> WE HAD GOOD TIMES, YOU KNOW WE TRAVELED EVERY WEEKEND TO A SPRINT CAR RACE AND A LOT OF US WERE-- HAD STEADY INDYCAR RIDES SO THERE WEREN'T AS MANY RACES AS THERE WAS ON THE SPRINT CAR CIRCUIT SO IT WAS, YOU KNOW, WE GOT TO BE-- GOT TO BE GOOD FRIENDS, BUT YOU KNOW, THERE IS ALWAYS A STORY THAT YOU DIDN'T GET TOO GOOD OF FRIENDS WITH THEM BECAUSE THEY MIGHT BE GONE NEXT WEEK, YOU KNOW.

WELL, THAT'S RACING, YOU KNOW AND IT'S AN UNFORTUNATE PART OF IT, BUT THAT'S SOMETIMES THE WAY IT GOES AND YOU KNOW, IT WASN'T GOING TO HAPPEN TO YOU.

>> NOBODY BACKS INTO A WIN HERE.

THE BIG HEROES ARE THE ONES THAT WIN THE BIG RACES HERE AND THAT'S BECAUSE THIS IS ONE OF THE TOUGHEST PLACES IN THE COUNTRY AS FAR AS DIRT TRACKS GO.

TO BE REALLY GOOD HERE, I MEAN THE HISTORY OF THIS PLACE WAS YOU HAD TO BE UP ON THE WALL AND RIGHT NEXT TO THE WALL.

AND IT'S A SPEED YOU ARE RUNNING, WHEN YOU ARE THAT CLOSE TO BEGIN WITH, IF SOMETHING HAPPENS AND YOU HAVE TO, YOU KNOW, CHASE THE CAR UP THE RACETRACK, THERE IS NOWHERE TO GO WHEN YOU ARE ALREADY THERE.

SO THE GUYS THAT HAD THE CONFIDENCE AND, YOU KNOW, WE ALWAYS JOKED AROUND ABOUT THE GUYS WITH THE BIGGEST BALLS WERE THE GUYS THAT RAN GOOD AT ELDORA.

>> WELL, ELORA WAS STARTED BY THE NAME OF EARL BALTES AND IT WASN'T THE TRACK IT WAS T IT JUST HAD A SINGLE GUARD RAIL, FAST, VERY HIGH BANKED.

AND YOU BOUNCED THEM OFF THE FENCE AND INITIALLY THEN IT GOT A DOUBLE GUARD RAIL AND THEN IT GOT A CONCRETE WALL.

BUT IT WAS SO HIGH BANKED AND SO FAST THAT IT EARNED A LOT OF RES OF A LOT OF PEOPLE.

THE TRACK GOT CHOPPY, YOU KNOW, THERE'D BE A LOT OF FLIPS BECAUSE OF THE SPEED AT WHICH THE FLIPS OCCURRED, IT NOT ONLY DAMAGED THE CARS, SOMETIMES IT DAMAGED THE DRIVER.

>> ONE OF THE MOST FAMOUS PHOTOS OF ELDORA SPEEDWAY IS JOHNNY RUTHERFORD FLIPPING ON TURN ONE, WITH THE CAR UPSIDE DOWN AND HIS ARMS STRAIGHT UP.

AND IT JUST SHOWED HOW TOUGH ELD WAS.

>> THAT WAS ONE OF THOSE THINGS THAT HAPPENED.

ONE OF THOSE THINGS THAT HAPPENED.

THE STORY I TELL ABOUT THIS PICTURE IS TONY STEWART TOLD ME THAT'S THE MOST FAMOUS PICTURE THAT WAS EVER MADE AT ELDORA, AN I HATED TO BE THE PARTICIPANT IN THE PICTURE, BUT THE NEXT DAY I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL, AND THE DAYTON DAILY NEWS IN THE SPORTS SECTION HAD A PICTURE OF ME ON THE FRONT PAGE OF THE SPORTS SECTION.

AND THE GUY THAT PUT IT THERE WROTE UNDERNEATH IT, RUTHERFORD WAVES TO THE CROWD AS HE LEAVES HE RACETRACK.

AND I HAVE YET TO FIND HIM.

(LAU >> THAT WAS THE TRAINING GROUND.

I MEAN THAT'S WHERE THE GUYS WHO HAD INDYCARS AND YOU KNOW, BACK WITH THE ROADSTERS, IF YOU RAN WELL IN SPRINT CARS, THAT'S HOW YOU MADE A NAME FOR YOURSELF.

THERE WASN'T SOCIAL MEDIA.

THERE WASN'T P.R.

AGENTS.

THERE WEREN'T PEOPLE TO-- THE ONLY WAY WERE YOU GOING TO GET RECOGNIZED TO GET GOOD OPPORTUNITIES WAS TO RUN WELL IN FRONT OF THOSE PEOPLE.

>> IN THE FALL OF 1961, HAROLD BECK, THE OWNER OF A SMALL CONSTRUCTION COMPANY IN DAYTON OHIO AND MID-LEVEL USAC SPRINT CAR PLUCKED THE 32-YEAR-OLD ROOKIE STAN BOWMAN OUT OF RELATIVE OBSCURITY.

LITTLE DID THEY KNOW, NINE MONTHS LATER, IN THE FIRST USAC SANCTIONED RACE AT ELDORA SPEEDWAY, THEY WOULD BE KNOCKING ON THE DOOR OF HISTORY.

>> HAROLD SCOUTED STAN BOWMAN AND GOING TO ELDORA AND LAWRENCEBURG.

AND I REMEMBER HIM TELLING ME, HE THINKS HE FOUND A DRIVER.

AND HAROLD FELT THAT IN FINDING A DRIVER LIKE STAN BOWMAN, HE DIDN'T HAVE PRECONCEIVED NOTIONS ABOUT HOW FAST THE CAR WAS GONNA BECAUSE HE KNEW STAN BOWMAN KNEW THAT THIS WAS PROBABLY GOING TO BE "THE" OPPORTUNITY TO GO UNDER THE NEXT RING OF RACING AND MAYBE BECOME AN INDIANAPOLIS WINNER PERHAPS.

IT WAS A STORMY DAY, AND STAN QUALIFIED WELL, GOT IN THE LEAD.

HE KNEW HOW TO READ A RACETRACK.

AND THIS IS SOMETHING THAT YOU DON'T GET IN A BOOK OR YOU CAN'T BE TOLD.

YOU EITHER HAVE IT OR YOU DON'T.

YOU CAN EITHER HIT 100 MILE AN HOUR FASTBALL, OR YOU WON'T.

HE HAD THIS ABILITY.

>> STAN WAS DRIVING A SPRINT CAR THAT HAD WHAT WAS CALLED AN OFFENHAUSER MOTOR IN IT.

AND THAT WAS VERY INTERESTING, AT THE TIME, BECAUSE OFFENHAUSER WAS KIND OF THE STANDARD MOTOR FOR SPRINT CARS FOR MANY YEARS UP UNTIL AROUND 1962.

CHEVROLET HAD INTRODUCED A CHEVROLET V8 INTO THE SCENE AND JONES-- PARNELLI JONES AND JIM HURTUBISE HAD CHEVY V8s.

IN FACT, THEY WERE ALREADY BEING CALLED THE CHEVY TWINS.

STAN CAME INTO THE RACE WITH AN UNDER PAR CAR AND STAN KNEW THAT AND EVERYBODY KNEW THAT, SO PROB A REASONABLE EXPECTATION FOR MOST PEOPLE IS THAT STAN MAYBE W BE A TOP 10 THAT DAY.

WHEN YOU LOOK AT THE NAMES THAT ARE THERE, AND YOU LOOK AT THE CARS AND THE OWNERS AND HERE'S HAROLD BECK WITH HIS SMALL OFFY, YES, THAT WAS THE EXPECTATION TO THE REASONABLE PERSON.

I WASN'T REASONABLE, BUT I WAS 10 YEARS OLD.

>> IT'S A PRETTY COOL LIST.

SO OBVIOUSLY STAN BOWMAN, JIM HURTUBISE, PARNELLI JONES, BOBBY MARSHMAN, ROGER McCLUSKEY, JOHNNY RUTHERFORD, DON BRANSON, ELMER GEORGE, ALLEN CROWE, BUD TINGELSTAD, COTTON FARMER, RONNIE DUNHAM, CHUCK RODEE, HUGH RANDALL, BOB MARVIN, LEON CLUM, TOM McCELLAN, JIM HEMMINGS, MICHEY SHAW AND ED TERRY AND PARNELLI JONES WAS QUICK TIME THAT NIGHT.

AND THE BEST PART WAS IT PAID $800 TO WIN.

FOR SURE, A THIRD OF THAT LIST MADE IT TO INDY AND WERE MAJOR NAMES IN OPEN WHEEL RACING.

>> STAN SEEMED TO BE PRETTY NERVOUS BECAUSE I THINK HE REALIZED THIS WAS HIS CHANCE.

HE QUALIFIED WELL, WHICH WAS A SURPRISE RIGHT THERE.

HE RAN WELL IN THE HEAT RACE.

AND HE STARTED, I THINK, THIRD IN THE FEATURE AND HE GOT TO THE LEAD.

>> SO THERE WAS STAN OUT FRONT AND THE CROWD WAS GOING CRAZY, INCLUDING ME.

I THINK EVERYBODY PROBABLY THOUGHT IT WAS TEMPORARY.

STAN BEING OUT FRONT.

THAT JIM HURTUBISE WOULD FIGURE OUT HOW TO GET BY HIM AND PARNELLI JONES, ROGER MCCLUSKEY AND AGAIN JOHNNY RUTHERFORD WAS WORKING HIS WAY UP THROUGH THE FIELD.

>> WHEN HE GOT TO THE LEAD, HE KNEW HOW TO WIN THE RACE.

AND HE PUT THE CAR IN A POSITION WHERE HE WASN'T TAKING UP THE RACETRACK, BUT THE OTHER DRIVER THAT WAS REALLY RUNNING VERY FAST BEHIND HIM, JIM HURTUBISE, A VERY ACCOMPLISHED DRIVER, HAD TO DRIVE AROUND HIM TO GET BY HIM.

STAN KNEW WHERE TO BE AND WHERE HURTUBISE WOULD HAVE TO BE TO TRY TO PASS HIM.

>> WHEN I SAW HIM, WHAT I SEE IS REALLY A SMART GUY.

ON DIRT TRACKS YOU NEED TO FIND WHAT I CALL THE SWEET SPOT.

HE TYPICALLY FOUND IT BEFORE EVERYBODY ELSE AND HE WORKED IT THE BETTER.

>> THE RACE SETTLED IN VERY QUICKLY TO A RACE WHERE STAN WAS BASICALLY HOLDING HIS OWN WITH THAT LITTLE RED OFFENHAUSER AND JIM HURTUBISE COULD GET NEXT TO HIM ON THE ONE LAP JIM HURTUBISE WOULD BE ON THE OUTSIDE OF HIM A NEXT LAP JIM HURTUBISE WOULD BR ON THE BOTTOM OF HIM, KIND OF TRYING TO DRIVE UNDERNEATH HIM.

JUST TRYING TO FIGURE OUT A WAY TO GET STAN TO MOVE ASIDE 'CAUSE I'M COMING THROUGH KIND OF ATTITUDE.

THAT'S THE ATTITUDE THESE DRIVERS HAD.

BUT STAN NEVER MOVED.

>> I WAS STANDING DOWN BETWEEN 3 AND 4, AND I WAS WATCHING HIS DRIVING AND HIS ATTITUDE WITH THE CAR.

THAT'S THE WAY HE PUT THE CAR INTO THE TURNS.

AND I WAS VERY IMPRESSED WITH THE WAY HE WAS DOING THE CAR AS A ROOKIE DRIVER.

>> THE BECK FAMILY.

THERE WAS HAROLD BECK IN THE INFIELD WITH HIS SON SONNY AND THEIR DAUGHTER, DIANE.

SHE WAS 16 YEARS OLD.

SHE WAS STANDING-- WOMEN COULD NOT GO IN THE PITS IN 1962.

BUT SHE WAS ALLOWED IN THE INFIELD.

SO SHE WAS STANDING IN THE BACK OF A PICKUP TRUCK STANDING OR JUMPING UP AND DOWN-- IS WHAT DIANE BECK TOLD ME-- GOING HYSTERICAL BECAUSE HER DADDY'S CAR WAS LEADING.

IN A USAC RACE.

AND IT JUST, I CAN'T EVEN IMAGINE WHAT THEY MUST HAVE BEEN GOING THROUGH THINKING ANY MOMENT HE'LL FINISH SECOND OR HE'LL FINISH FOURTH OR SOMETHING WILL HAPPEN TO THE CAR, AND IT DIDN'T.

IT JUST DIDN'T.

>> MANY, MANY DRIVERS, INCLUDING MANY VETERAN DRIVERS, WHEN THEY GET TO A POINT LIKE THIS THAT THEY'RE LEADING, AND THEY HAVE SOMEBODY ON THEIR TAIL THAT'S QUITE ACCOMPLISHED, THEY GET RATTLED, AND THEY MAKE MISTAKES AND THEY GET PASSED.

AND JIM HURTUBISE WAS RIGHT BEHIND HIM, WAS A VERY ACCOMPLISHED DRIVER AND HAD A LOT OF SKILLS.

AND JIM HAD EVERY TRICK IN THE BOOK DOWN FROM YEARS OF RACING IN MANY RACES.

AND JIM COULDN'T PULL IT OFF.

>> SO WHAT HAPPENED ON ABOUT LAP 26, IT STARTED RAINING.

THE FLAGMAN HAD A YELLOW FLAG TO SLOW DOWN THE RACE BECAUSE THE RAIN WOULD MAKE THE TRACK UNDRIVEABLE.

AND I'M SURE-- I JUST KNOW-- THAT STAN BOWMAN AND HURTUBISE, THEY KNEW WHAT WAS COMING.

THEY FELT THE RAIN.

AND I'M SURE HURTUBISE THOUGHT HE HAD ONE MORE LAP TO GET HIM.

AND I'LL NEVER FORGET THAT ON THAT LAST GREEN LAP, HURTUBISE CAME UP TO THE SIDE, I THINK HURTUBISE PROBABLY COULD HAVE READ THE GAUGES IN STAN'S CAR THEY WERE THAT CLOSE GOING DOWN THE BACKSTRETCH.

AND STAN HELD ON GOING THROUGH THREE AND FOUR AND CAME ACROSS AND THEY THREW THE YELLOW FLAG AND THEN IT STARTED POURING DOWN RAIN.

AND ON THE NEXT LAP, THEY THREW THE RED FLAG AND THE RACE WAS OFFICIALLY OVER.

I THINK A LAP SHORT OF 30 OR TWO LAPS SHORT OF 30.

STAN PULLED INTO THE INFIELD.

IMMEDIATELY THE CROWD GATHERED BECAUSE HE WON THE RACE.

I SAW THE BECK FAMILY RUN UP TO HIM, DIANE BECK.

HER DAD MUST HAVE BEEN SO PROUD.

AND HER SON.

AND JIM HURTUBISE WALKED UP AFTER THE RACE, AND DIANE BECK TOLD ME, HE DIDN'T SAY A WORD.

HE JUST LOOKED AT STAN AND WINKED AND WALKED AWAY.

HE HAD TAKEN MONEY OUT OF THE POCKETS OF SOME DRIVERS THAT DAY AND THEY DROVE FOR MONEY IN THOSE DAYS.

SO THEY KNEW STAN BOWMAN WAS THERE, AND IT WAS THE REAL DEAL.

THE CROWD KNEW IT AND I ALWAYS KNEW IT.

>> WAS IT A SURPRISE THAT HE WON?

YES, IT WAS, WITH PARNELLI AND McCLUSKEY AND ALL OF US IN THAT RACE, IT WAS, YOU KNOW, IT SHOWED WHAT STAN HAD AND WHAT HE COULD PRODUCE WITH.

>> THAT WAS THE FIRST USAC RACE THEY EVER RAN AT ELDORA.

AND STAN TOOK 'EM TO SCHOOL THAT DAY.

HE TOOK 'EM TO SCHOOL.

UNBELIEVABLE.

>> TO BE IN THAT KIND OF A RACE WITH THOSE DRIVERS, DRIVERS ON THAT LEVEL TO BE JUST THROWN INTO THAT KIND OF BATTLE IS JUST HARD TO IMAGINE, YOU KNOW.

YOU THINK YOU ARE GOOD AT WHAT YOU DO UNTIL YOU ARE PUT AGAINST THE BEST.

AND HE WAS THRUSTED AGAINST THE BEST RIGHT AWAY AND PREVAILED.

>> IN AN ERA WHERE THE MOTORS WERE CHANGING AND CHEVROLET HAD COME INTO THE SPORT AND THE CHEVY MOTORS WERE REALLY STARTING TO FINALLY BEAT THE OFFENHAUSER, THAT WAS KIND-OF TH IF YOU WANTED TO WIN, YOU WANTED A SHOT TO WIN, YOU REALLY NEEDED TO HAVE A CHEVY, AND THAT'S WAS THE PERCEPTION.

AND HERE STAN CAME IN WITH AN OFFENHAUSER AND STILL KICKED THEIR BUTT.

>> STAN'S NEXT USAC SPRINT CAR RACE WOULD BE ANOTHER CHALLENGE, THIS TIME DRIVING ON PAVEMENT AT THE FAMOUS SALEM SPEEDWAY.

>> WELL, SALEM WAS LIKE THE PAVED ELDORA.

IT WAS HIGH BANKED.

WE HAD THREE TRACKS THAT WE RAN A LONG TIME AGO, WINCHESTER INDIANA, SALEM INDIANA AND DAYTON, OHIO.

AND WERE ALL HIGH BANKED TRACKS AND THEY WERE EXTREMELY FAST BEING ON PAVEMENT.

THEY WEREN'T ALWAYS NICE AND SMOOTH AND THEY WERE YOU RUDDY OR ONE THING OR ANOTHER.

NOT RUDDY BUT THEY HAD BUMPS IN THEM AND WOULD MAKE THE CARS DANCE AROUND.

>> I ENJOYED RACING ON THE HILLS AND I HAD A LOT OF LUCK RACING ON THE HILLS, WE CALLED THEM.

YOU KNOW, THERE AGAIN IT WAS ONE OF THOSE THINGS, YOU KNOW, FIRST PAVEMENT THAT I REALLY RAN AT IMCA WAS AT SALEM ONCE.

AND IT WAS FAST ENOUGH, YOU GET IN THE CORNER AND IT WOULD GET SIDEWAYS.

SO I HAD TO LEARN HOW TO DO THAT.

>> I FLEW OUT OF SALEM AND NOT IN AN AIRPLANE.

I WENT OUT IN A SPRINT CAR OVER THE FENCE IN TURN ONE.

I WAS RUNNING THIRD WHEN I RAN OVER BUTLER'S RIGHT REAR WITH THE LEFT FRONT.

AND IT JUST CAUGHT THE TOP OF THE FENCE, BUT WENT ON OVER AND IN THE BACKGROUND, YOU SEE THE TREES.

WELL, THE TREES ARE WHAT I WENT THROUGH TO GET DOWN TO THE GROUND, WHICH LUCKILY THE BRANCHES HELPED SLOW IT DOWN.

BUT OFF OF THE TURN ONE AND TWO INTO THE RACETRACK IS AN AIRPORT AND I LANDED DOWN FAR ENOUGH DOWN THE BANKING THROUGH THE TREES TO WHERE IT WAS DOWN WHERE THEY ACTUALLY CUT THE GRASS BESIDE THE RUNWAY.

>> ONE OF HIS CAR OWNERS TOLD ME ONE TIME AT SALEM, HE SAID HE WAS STANDING DOWN BETWEEN 1 AND 2.

HE SAID WHEN BOWMAN 20 THROUGH THE CORNER, HE SAID ALL FOUR TIRES HAD SMOKE ROLLING OFF OF T THAT'S PRETTY BRAVE.

>> STAN BOWMAN WAS A DIRT TRACK DRIVER.

STAN BOWMAN WAS NOT A PAVEMENT ASPHALT DRIVER.

AND SOME DRIVERS WERE VERY GOOD ON ASPHALT.

AND SOME DRIVERS WERE VERY GOOD ON DIRT.

AND THERE WERE A FEW, A.J.

FOYT, PARNELLI JONES, THE NAMES THAT WERE GOOD ON BOTH, IT WAS GOING TO BE A TEST FOR STAN TO SEE IF HE COULD EVEN REALLY COMPETE ON A PAVEMENT TRACK.

AND HE DID.

>> DESPITE HIS LACK OF EXPERIENCE ON PAVEMENT, STAN SPED TO A FOURTH PLACE FINISHBEHIND DON BRANSON, ELMER GEORGE AND PARNELLI JONES.

HOWEVER, AFTER THE RACE, HE WAS PENALIZED TWO POSITIONS FOR PASSING DURING A CAUTION FLAG.

SOME BELIEVE THE PENALTY WAS ACTUALLY A WARNING BY THE OFFICIALS TO THE ROOKIE DRIVER AS AN ATTEMPT TO SLOW HIM DOWN.

THE FOLLOWING WEEKEND, HE RETURNED TO A DIRT TRACK AT NEW BREMEN OHIO, FINISHING THIRD THAT DAY TO JIM HURTUBISE AND PARNELLI JONES.

STAN WAS SENDING A CLEAR MESSAGE TO THE OTHER DRIVERS THAT THEY WOULD NOW BE CONTENDING WITH A HOT SHOT ROOKIE FROM COVINGTON, KENTUCKY.

>> I WAS UP AT NEW BREMEN, AND THE CAR OWNER, HAROLD BECK, THAT HE WAS DRIVING FOR, HE WENT OUT ON THE TRACK AND HE WAS POINTING AND GOING LIKE THIS TO HURTUBISE WHO WAS LEADING IT.

AND BOWMAN IS SITTING THERE WITH ONE HAND ON IT AND HE'S GOING LIKE THAT WAS POINTING, SAYING I'M AFTER HIM.

HE NEVER CAUGHT HIM, BUT IT WASN'T FOR TRYING.

>> IN STAN'S SECOND GO AROUND ON PAVEMENT AT INDIANAPOLIS RACEWAY PARK, HE BROKE A TRACK RECORD DURING A SIX-LAP HEAT RACE.

THE BECK CAR SEEMED UNSTOPPABLE WITH STAN BEHIND THE WHEEL.

BUT IN THE FUTURE RACE, AS STAN FLEW DOWN THE BACKSTRETCH ON THE FIRST LAP, THE CRANK SHAFT BROKE CAUSING THE MOTOR TO EXPLODE IN A RAGE OF SMOKE AND FIRE.

>> BY STAN PUT HIS HANDS UP, HE WARNED THE OTHER DRIVERS, I'VE BROKEN SOMETHING SERIOUS.

GET AWAY FROM ME BECAUSE I COULD BE DUMPING OIL OUT, PARTS OUT.

HE DIDN'T KNOW.

WHEN THE CRANK SHAFT BROKE IN THE OFFENHAUSER THAT DAY, HE HAD ALREADY WON THE HEAT RACE GOING AWAY.

HE WAS OBVIOUSLY FLYING THAT DAY.

BUT FOR AN OFFENHAUSER ENGINE TO KEEP UP WITH THE CHEVROLETS, IT HAS TO BE WOUND AS TIGHT AS IT CAN GO.

YOU ARE REALLY ASKING EVERYTHING OUT OF THAT ENGINE IT CAN GIVE.
